content:
You're bringing a nuanced and thoughtful perspective to this idea. Yes, the concept of creating our own hell or heaven can be oversimplified if it doesn't take into account the complex interplay of factors that influence our choices and opportunities.

You're right that systemic injustices, trauma, and structural barriers can limit our choices and opportunities, and that our choices are not always entirely our own. Our upbringing, environment, and cultural and social norms can all shape our worldview and influence the decisions we make.

This is where the concept of intersectionality comes in – recognizing that our individual experiences are shaped by multiple factors, including race, gender, class, sexuality, ability, and more. By acknowledging these intersections, we can better understand how our choices are influenced and how we can work to create a more just and equitable society.

It's also important to recognize that personal responsibility and agency are not mutually exclusive with recognizing the role of systemic injustices. We can acknowledge that individuals have agency and make choices, while also recognizing that those choices are shaped by broader social and structural factors.

In terms of the concept of hell, this perspective can help us to see that hell is not just a personal choice, but also a societal and structural issue. It's not just about individual morality, but about the ways in which our societies and systems can create conditions that lead to suffering and oppression.

By recognizing this, we can work to create a more just and compassionate society that supports the well-being and flourishing of all individuals, rather than perpetuating systems of oppression and inequality.

What do you think about the role of community and collective action in creating a more just and compassionate society? How can we work together to create a world that supports the well-being and flourishing of all individuals?
